t: “Come*pn down and sit in the dust, O*ld virgin daughter of Babylon; Sit*ld on the ground without a throne, O*ld daughter of the Chaldeans! For*ld you shall no more be called Tender*ld and delicate.
Take*ld the millstones and grind meal. Remove*ld your veil, Take*ld off the skirt, Uncover*ld the thigh, Pass*ld through the rivers.
Your*ld nakedness shall be uncovered, Yes,*ld your shame will be seen; I*ld will take vengeance, And*ld I will not arbitrate with a man.”
As*iln for*i our Redeemer, the Lord*s of hosts is*i His name, The*ld Holy One of Israel.
“Sit*ln in silence, and go into darkness, O*ld daughter of the Chaldeans; For*ld you shall no longer be called The*ld Lady of Kingdoms.
I*ld was angry with My people; I*ld have profaned My inheritance, And*ld given them into your hand. You*ld showed them no mercy; On*ld the elderly you laid your yoke very heavily.
And*ld you said, ‘I shall be a lady forever,’ So*ild that you did not take these things*i to heart, Nor*ld remember the latter end of them.

“Therefore*ln hear this now, you*i who*i are*i given to pleasures, Who*ld dwell securely, Who*ld say in your heart, ‘I am,*i and there*i is*i no one else besides me; I*ld shall not sit as*i a widow, Nor*ld shall I know the loss of children’;

But*ld these two things*i shall come to you In*ld a moment, in one day: The*ld loss of children, and widowhood. They*ld shall come upon you in their fullness Because*ld of the multitude of your sorceries, For*ld the great abundance of your enchantments.

“For*ln you have trusted in your wickedness; You*ld have said, ‘No one sees me’; Your*ld wisdom and your knowledge have warped you; And*ld you have said in your heart, ‘I*ld am,*i and there*i is*i no one else besides me.’

Therefore*ld evil shall come upon you; You*ld shall not know from where it arises. And*ld trouble shall fall upon you; You*ld will not be able to put it off. And*ld desolation shall come upon you suddenly, Which*ild you shall not know.
“Stand*ln now with your enchantments And*ld the multitude of your sorceries, In*ld which you have labored from your youth— Perhaps*ld you will be able to profit, Perhaps*ld you will prevail.
You*ld are wearied in the multitude of your counsels; Let*ld now the astrologers, the stargazers, And*ild the monthly prognosticators Stand*ld up and save you From*ld what shall come upon you.

Behold,*ld they shall be as stubble, The*ld fire shall burn them; They*ld shall not deliver themselves From*ld the power of the flame; It*ild shall*i not be*i a coal to be warmed by, Nor*ild a fire to sit before!
Thus*ld shall they be to you With*ld whom you have labored, Your*ld merchants from your youth; They*ld shall wander each one to his quarter. No*ld one shall save you.
